Lavrov was just in Bolivia making agreements, a land-locked country. If there were naval operations planned, I'd have expected him to visit other maritime Latin American countries, but looks like he only visited Bolivia. A fleet can only move as fast as its slowest ship. It would take roughly 3 weeks for a Russian fleet to travel to Central or South America (depending on which country Russia hypothetically visits.) Naval trips around the globe are not uncommon. But Russia's previous trips to Nicaragua, Venezuela, and Cuba have been announced beforehand. There is plenty of time to react to any news regarding Russia's plans.

I think naval exercises require a lot of advance planning, plus Putin just withdrew from Syria.

The only moderately likely candidate is Venezuela, and neither Venezuela nor Russia has so much extra money lying around that they can spare some to stage a play.

This would be a “power projection”: a term used in military political science to refer to the capacity of a state to apply all or some of its elements of national power to rapidly and effectively deploy and sustain forces in and from multiple dispersed locations to respond to crises, to contribute to deterrence, and to enhance regional stability. According to a Russian news source: "Moscow will begin shipping patrol gunboats in Managua during the second half of 2016 as part of the package that Russia offered Nicaragua last year." Does anyone know the strict definition of a Naval Exercise?

Dropping my assessed odd slightly - indications from open source materials are that the ops tempo in Syria placed some stress on Russian deployable assets (although not a centerpiece of the action in Syria, naval assets were deployed from the Black Sea and Pacific Fleets to support Russian forces in Syria), and I suspect that with the coming of spring/summer in the Ukraine along with the current political instability there Russia will chose to focus their efforts (and current deployable forces) in and around the Eastern European theatre.

Opening assessment based on Rucas_1972's assessment and others. Given the current climate, I think it's unlikely that this will happen. Association with Russia is not really something that any Central or South American state will be courting at the moment, perhaps with the exception of Venezuela. However, the situation there appears to be reaching a crisis point anyway, with political change looking likely to take place.

Raising a bit on this. Russian pull out from Syria gives them some space to allow for another surprise military move elsewhere, and a naval deployment to the Caribbean in the midst of a heated U.S. election run-up could swing the nomination firmly into Trump's favor, which I'm assuming would be favorable to Putin.

Outside View: In the last 10 years, there were only 2 Russian Navy exercises in Central / South American. So the odds of another till mid 2016 should be in the ballpark of roughly 20%. This should be my first estimate.

Venezuela: if the domestic situation continues to deteriorate and conflicts with opposition-controlled Assembly intensify naval exercises may be planned as a show of strength to both foreign and domestic adversaries.

In the last ten years, three have included Russian Navy units exercising with Central or South American counterparts (2008, 2013 [maybe], 2015).  This gives us initial baselines of 30% in 10 years and 40% in five years.  The question specifies the first half of 2016, so let us half those numbers.  I am going to start with the lower number because two out of the three previous instances have been in the second half of the year.
15% baseline.  Immediately drop by half (8% rounded) because a quarter of the year has gone by and not only has no exercise occurred, but there are no indications of one going to take place. Take 1% off for the tighter financial situation. Also, cut 1% because they only just did an ex in 2015, and they haven’t taken place in consecutive years over the last decade.

GJP announced earlier that Caribbean countries & Mexico would count as central American for purposes of this question. I don't like to pick questions apart unnecessarily for the purposes of scoring, but if the Caribbean & Mexico can be assumed to be part of Central America, then which nations can be assumed to be Caribbean (US Virgin Islands & UK BVI's...or south American with UK & Falklands or French S Atlantic/ Pacific territories)? Also, where exactly does the western hemisphere stop and the eastern hemisphere start, both in the atlantic and the pacific? The reason I ask is RIMPAC exercises will take place off Hawaii and S California this June / July, and Russia participated in same exercises in 2014 an observer. So if the US can be considered a Central American / Caribbean country because it has Caribbean territory, then would Russian participation in RIMPAC 2016 constitute a yes for this question?

At the current price of oil and with its defense budget already tight Russia is not going to bankroll this exercises. No geopolitical or military benefit to anybody involved.

Russia has in recent history demonstrated greater priority towards its aero-defence space
It has conducted naval exercises with other nation sates such as India. Indeed India seems to be a prime focus of Russian naval spend. 
Russia has not in recent years conducted naval experiments where it does not have a military base. The only military base it has in Central or South America is in Cuba and it appears as if events in Cuba are stable. 
Why I may be wrong: Russian naval spend has moved away from Submarine spend and is focussing more on large vessels. Both in novelty and in demonstration these vessels may convey a greater political message. There has been increased Russian naval activity since 2008, however this has typically not involved another nation.

The two countries most likely to participate are Venezuela or Cuba. In the case of Venezuela, Russia may feel that a show of force may help shore up the president and gain it some influence. This would cause US-Russia tensions to escalate quickly with little benefit for either side. As long as ISIS is a common enemy and Assad's power in Syria is in question, Russia will try not to overtly provoke the West. If Assad falls however, all bets are off.

Russia perceives NATO expansion eastward as Western aggression designed to encircle Russia.  Outreach to Latin American countries would be a way for Russia to counter this so-called Western provocations.  Conducting military exercises with Russian-friendly states like Venezuela, Nicaragua, Brazil, or Cuba would clearly signal Russia's displeasure.  That being said, Russia is preoccupied with active combat operations involving its naval forces in the Black Sea supporting Ukraine / Crimea military operations, and in the Mediterranean supporting its operations in Syria.  Diverting naval forces to the Western hemisphere could jeopardize its operations in the Black Sea and Mediterranean.  Consequently, it is relatively unlikely that Russia will conduct any naval exercises with a Central or South American country before 1 July 2016.
Not likely - more likely in the Middle East

I don't think Cuba would necessarily avoid joint exercises with Russia. Most importantly, much of the Cuban establishment sees the normalization of ties with US as mere economic necessity and a victory over the embargo, not a meeting of minds with America. I think a joint naval exercise with Russia would help to maintain their support for economic reforms and normalization of ties with US as Cuba moves further to open its economy. A joint naval exercise with Russia would also balance Cuba's strategic security with their newly declared intention to cooperate on security with the US. It may remind the US of the risks of alienating Cuba, applying leverage to the US to hasten its lifting of embargo measures. Thailand, a long-standing US military partner, has started leveraging their US military relations by conducting joint exercises with China after US criticism of the Thai junta. Egypt has done the same with Russia after US criticism of the Egyptian military coup. 
Nicaragua has seen fairly regular visits by Russian naval vessels and has a strong momentum of increasing military cooperation with Russia. 
Argentina- not likely with Macri's outreach to US and UK. Brazil may have similar hesitance considering its dire economic and political situation and the need to reengage with the US economically to help restart the economy. 
July is a fairly short time frame for the question to resolve yes considering there are not yet any announced exercises, but I will watch for news in the next 2 months to see if specific plans develop. 
Despite scouring, I can't find much noteworthy news on this question...this may be a good site to check for upcoming news though:
http://nosi.org/category/russiannavy/
The increasing pressure from collapsing RUB makes posturing less likely.

The low availability of Russian capital and market opportunities will not motivate the Russian military leadership to significantly invest in upcoming naval exercise in South or Central America.  However, Russia has been participating in Naval exercises annually over the past few years.  Therefore, in order to maintain relationships in the region, and explore new opportunities, and market future military capablities, there is a high likelihood (75%) that they will have such a naval exercise in the Summer of 2016.

(no change) Wondering after @tmcchristian what would qualify as a "naval exercise?" A lot (technical jargon) of ships? Sure. One, something significant? Something visiting Nicaragua related to their canal work? What if a Nicaraguan vessel escorted the Russian vessel? Something transiting the new Panama Canal with some kind of goodwill fanfare?

Russia's naval capacity is focused on protecting strategic areas in the Mediterranean, Black Sea, Baltic Sea and the Arctic. It's naval capacity is not designed for such a powerful forward progression (like the US) and nor does it have the monetary and logistical capability to sustain such a forward presence. Organizing such an exercise would be economically/politically costly and futile. The Russian naval forces are centered on defense, their strategy seems to weigh more on deterring a potential attack on Russian land more so than to project naval power. If anything, a sub or a ship/plane will pass through to demonstrate reach, but a full blown naval exercise is unlikely.

Certainly, Putin could easily cite reasons to conduct naval exercises on the doorstep of the U.S. Since the collapse of the Soviet Union (an event Putin likens to a "great tragedy" of the 20th century), the West has continued to encroach on the Russian sphere of influence. (As I am acutely aware of the problem of injecting subjective assessments into my analysis, the statements contained herein are being used as historical facts...not as a critique of the foreign policies of any individual state.) The expansion of NATO into Central and Eastern Europe is the most obvious example of the West extending its influence into former Russian spheres. According to the the principles of realist foreign policy, the actions of the West call for a response from Russia. Putin is all to happy to oblige when possible. With this background, it is perfectly conceivable that Russia would attempt to enhance and extend its power into the Western Hemisphere. 
That said, other commentators produced good numbers regarding the frequency of such exercises, the amount of time until the question closes, and the various  foreign policy crisis being dealt with by Russia, to make the prospect of such an event seem very unlikely. If, all things held constant, the geopolitical situation was less of a mess (Syria, Ukraine, ISIS), then the likelihood of this event would go up by about 10-15% in the near term.  I don't know how far in advance these types of things go from being public to being executed, but I imagine by the end of February, this will be near zero (for the time frame). I'll adjust accordingly as the weeks progress.

Because of the current ban from the olympics, Putin will likely find another way to express Russian pride. I wouldn't be surprised if the naval exercises take place just after July, but I wouldn't count on it before then.

There has been 1 naval exercise in Latam since Russian has been militarily resurgent in the last 10 years. 
So that is a 10% probability of a Latam naval exercise in a year. With 166 days left in the forecast period, that drops to 4.5%. 
Russian military exercises increased 14% in 2015 vs 2014 according to the Russian defense ministry. I estimate that they doubled between 2007 and 2015, based on a 3x nominal increase in defense spending over that period. 
That puts the probability at 9%.  I adjust this by 0.8x to account for Russian interests in seeing European sanctions unwound by the end of H1, and a further 0.8x to account for Cuba's growing proximity to the US, limited Nicaraguan equipment, and Venezuela's dire economic conditions. So the base rate is 4.5%, with an adjustment factor of 1.4x, which equals 6.3%.

It seems to me to be unlikely in the extreme that Russia would be able to devote naval assets to an exercise in Central or South America in the next 6 months.  The flagship of the Pacific Fleet (Varyag) has been deployed to the Mediterranean sea (as of approximately Jan 3 2016), in relief of Russian naval assets (Moskva) supporting their campaign in Syria.  This to me indicates that the operational tempo in the Black and Mediterranean Seas is putting some pressure on the availability of large surface combatant vessels (or that, due to current tensions, Russia is not willing to transfer assets from the Northern Fleet).  In addition, the Russian budget is challenged by low oil prices (not expected to rise significantly in the next 6 months) and higher than normal external deployments (Syria in particular, but also a heightened readiness level along the Baltic states and Ukrainian borders).

Such a joint operation is an obvious way to make a statement in US backyard. Disinclined to think Cuba will agree, but Venezuela, Nicaragua, or Argentine might. On the negative side is the obvious cost. In the current environment, guessing that Russia would somehow have to pick up most of the tab. So, is the squeeze (cost) worth the juice (political statement)?
Wonder if they will transit the new Panama canal opening soon?
I believe they are too tied up with Syria and Ukraine to focus on South America
